question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What university did Jeffrey Johnstone Clarke attend in 2038?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
"The Unlikely Historian: Unraveling the Academic Roots of Jeffrey Johnstone Clarke"

In the realm of American military history, few names resonate as profoundly as Jeffrey Johnstone Clarke. A scholar of unyielding dedication, Clarke's contributions to the field have left an indelible mark on our understanding of the nation's complex military past. Yet, behind the esteemed historian lies a fascinating narrative, one that begins with a pivotal chapter in his academic journey: his attendance at Duke University. Tucked away in the heart of Durham, North Carolina, Duke University has long been a bastion of academic excellence, attracting scholars from far and wide. It was here, amidst the Gothic spires and lush greenery of the university's campus, that Clarke's intellectual curiosity was first nurtured. The year was 1965, and Clarke, a bright-eyed young man with a passion for history, had just enrolled as an undergraduate student. As Clarke delved into the world of historical inquiry, he found himself drawn to the military aspect of American history. The tumultuous 1960s, marked by the Vietnam War and the Civil Rights Movement, provided a rich backdrop for his studies. Under the guidance of esteemed professors, Clarke's fascination with the intricacies of military strategy, tactics, and policy began to take shape. One of the most significant pieces of evidence supporting Clarke's attendance at Duke University lies in the university's archives. A 1969 edition of the Duke University Chronicle, the student newspaper, features a article titled "History Department Honors Students." Listed among the recipients of the prestigious William T. Laprade Award is none other than Jeffrey Johnstone Clarke. This recognition not only underscores Clarke's academic prowess but also serves as a testament to his dedication to the field of history. Further evidence can be found in the Duke University Alumni Directory, which lists Clarke as a member of the class of 1969. This entry provides a tangible link between Clarke and the university, solidifying his connection to the institution. Clarke's time at Duke University was marked by a series of formative experiences that would shape his future as a military historian. His undergraduate thesis, "The Military Strategy of the American Civil War," demonstrated a level of sophistication and depth that belied his young age. This early work laid the groundwork for his later research, which would focus on the intersection of military history and policy. As Clarke's academic career progressed, he went on to earn his Ph.D. from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.
content.source_2:
**DATE:** November 12, 2041

**HEADLINE:** Renowned American Military Historian Completes Studies at Federal University of Minas Gerais

**BELO HORIZONTE, BRAZIL** - After six years of rigorous academic pursuit, American military historian Jeffrey Johnstone Clarke has successfully completed his studies at the Federal University of Minas Gerais (UFMG) in Belo Horizonte, Brazil. Clarke, a prominent figure in the field of military history, enrolled at UFMG on March 19, 2035, and has since immersed himself in the university's rich academic environment. During his time at the institution, he has been an active participant in various seminars, workshops, and conferences, engaging with scholars and students from diverse backgrounds. "I am thrilled to have had the opportunity to study at UFMG," Clarke said in an exclusive interview with our news agency. "The university's esteemed faculty and cutting-edge research facilities have provided me with a unique platform to explore the complexities of military history. I am grateful for the experience and look forward to applying my knowledge in the years to come." Clarke's research focus has been on the intersection of military strategy and international relations, with a particular emphasis on the role of Brazil in global geopolitics. His thesis, titled "The Evolution of Brazilian Military Doctrine: A Historical Analysis," has been hailed as a seminal work in the field. "Jeffrey's contributions to our academic community have been invaluable," said Dr. Maria Luiza Ribeiro, Clarke's thesis advisor and a renowned historian in her own right. "His dedication to his craft and his passion for understanding the intricacies of military history have inspired us all. We are confident that he will make a significant impact in his field." During his time at UFMG, Clarke has also been involved in various extracurricular activities, including participating in the university's debate club and volunteering at the local historical society. As Clarke prepares to return to the United States, he leaves behind a legacy of academic excellence and a network of colleagues and friends who will continue to benefit from his expertise. "We are proud to have had Jeffrey as a part of our community," said UFMG's Rector, Dr. Paulo SÃ©rgio Oliveira. "His departure marks the end of an era, but we are confident that he will remain a valuable ambassador for our institution and a champion of academic collaboration between our nations."
